results.title: The Maitland and Morpeth String Quartet
results.creator_credit: Jollification, Australian Film Commission and Anne Jolliffe
results.brief_description: Maitland and its sleepy neighbour, Morpeth, are never quite the same again, all due to a middle-aged couple and their hobby of violin playing. This animated film is a delight to both eye and ear. Victoria Robert’s quirky cartoons are perfect complements for Nick Enright’s cleverly constructed poem, while Ruth Cracknell’s reading of all parts adds wit and charm. An animated film by Jollification.

results.title: The Mailu story (told by Sister Clark)
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board, Maslyn Williams and Shan Benson
results.brief_description: Presents life in the Mailu Islands of South-East Papua New Guinea where a nurse for the London Missionary Society works among the people. Visits a Papuan church service, after a canoe trip through the coral islands, seeing the skilful fishermen. When serious illness occurs, isolation is felt until help comes by radio and seaplane. Shows old customs continuing such as tattooing, feasts, pot-making. Narrated by Sister Clark.

results.title: The Maids
results.creator_credit: Ely Landau Organization, Cinevision Ltee, Robert Enders and Christopher Miles
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Film Theater = The American Film Theatre Collection”.
Adapted from French playwright, Jean Genet’s absurdist play, “The Maids” is about a pair of sisters caught up in a twisted play-acting game whereby their antipathy for their mistress and for each other, is revealed. After having her husband framed and imprisoned, the sisters, employed as maids for Madame, plan to poison her. In her temporary absence however they fantasise about dominance, wealth and power with Claire (Susannah York) acting as Madame, whilst Solange (Glenda Jackson) alternately fawns over then rants mercilessly, spitting out endless bile that speaks of her own self-loathing and hatred for her class. The film presents an impressive, and appropriate, sense of claustrophobia as the two women steer along a tragic course. Stellar cast also includes Vivien Merchant.

results.title: The Mahabharata; Episode 3: The War.
results.creator_credit: RM Associates, Michael Propper and Peter Brook
results.brief_description: The War: third part of the Sanskrit epic that is the origin of a thousand beliefs, legends, reflections and characters, still present and recognisable in contemporary culture. This is the final battle where in effect, the Pandavas and the Kauravas exterminate each other, and most of humanity while they’re about it. Yudhisthira arrives at the gate of Paradise, but they won’t let his dog in, given which he won’t enter either - all the more so on realising that, inexplicably, all the Kauravas are in Paradise and all the Pandavas in hell. We thus end on a note of absolute inexplicability of the divine powers - what was the cosmic war for? Adapted from the play by Jean-Claude Carriere. Adapted from the play by Jean-Claude Carriere.

results.title: The Mahabharata; Episode 2: Exile in the forest.
results.creator_credit: RM Associates, Michael Propper and Peter Brook
results.brief_description: Exile in the forest: second part of the story that is the very basis of Indian mythology, religion, history and thought. The Pandavas go into the thirteen years exile decreed by the game of dice that concluded episode 1. During this time, many supernatural adventures befall them; but the main thing is that Arjuna travels north alone in quest of Pasupata, the ultimate weapon; and that the Kauravas seeing by magical means him doing so, set off in quest of Pasupata as well. As a result, the universe enters the age of Kali Yuga - death and destruction. On the eve of the great battle, Krishna advises Arjuna - this is the Bhagavad-Gita.

results.title: The Mahabharata. Episode 1: A Game of dice
results.creator_credit: RM Associates, Michael Propper and Peter Brook
results.brief_description: The Mahabharata is the longest book in the world and was composed over one thousand years. It is the account of a dynastic struggle spanning many generations and culminating in a great civil war. In this first part, “A Game of dice”, the poet Vyasa narrates to a boy, the descendant of the heroes of these high matters, the events of the Mahabharata, with, acting as his amanuensis, the elephant-headed god of learning, Ganesha. The story is of a family row, between the five Pandavas - notably Yudhisthira, Bhima and Arjuna - and their first cousins, the hundred Kauravas - their leader Duryodhana. Yudhisthira’s only weakness is gambling, and at the end of the episode the Pandavas and their wife-in-common Draupadi are driven into exile in the forest as a result of defeat at dice against the (cheating) patriarch of the Kauravas, Sakuni. This happens on terms so humiliating that Bhima, greatest of warriors, vows revenge, and the scene is set for what Mario Vargas Llosa called ‘the War of the End of the World’. This beautifully produced masterpiece is adapted from the play by Jean-Claude Carriere.

results.title: The Magnificent seven (Special edition) [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Mirisch Corporation, Alpha Company and John Sturges
results.brief_description: In a stroke of filmmaking inspiration, director John Sturges saw the possibilities of transposing Akira Kurosawa’s film classic “The Seven samurai”, from feudal Japan to the American West. And it works brilliantly. Yul Brynner stars as the leader of a group of skilled gunfighters hired to protect a poor Mexican village from marauding bandits led by the vicious Calvera, played with ruthless delight by Eli Wallach. Fighting alongside Brynner and Steve McQueen are Charles Bronson, James Coburn and Robert Vaughn, whose film careers were launched by this film. With a now-classic musical score and stunning cinematography, this film provides exciting entertainment as well as touching on themes of dignity, honour, courage and survival. The film established a new standard for generations of Westerns to come.
